<TYPE>EX-32.1
<SEQUENCE>6
<FILENAME>ex32-1.htm
<DESCRIPTION>EX-32.1
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
     <TITLE></TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif">

<P STYLE="margin: 0"></P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center"><FONT STYLE="text-transform: uppercase">Exhibit</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="color: black">32.1 </FONT></P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center">Certification of the Chief Executive Officer
pursuant to 18 U.S.C. Section 1350,</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center">as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley
Act of 2002</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">In connection with this annual report of Espey Mfg. &amp; Electronics
Corp. (the &quot;Company&quot;) on Form 10-K for the period ended June 30, 2012 as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission
on the date hereof (the &ldquo;report&rdquo;), I, Mark St. Pierre, President and Chief Executive Officer of the Company, certify,
pursuant to 18 U.S.C. Section 1350, as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that to my knowledge:</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">&nbsp;</P>

<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.5in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.5in">1.</TD><TD>The report fully complies with the requirements of Section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934; and</TD></TR></TABLE>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.5in">&nbsp;</P>

<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.5in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.5in">2.</TD><TD>The information contained in this report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of
operations of the Company.</TD></TR></TABLE>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">Date: September 13, 2012</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">&nbsp;</P>

<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" STYLE="width: 100%; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; border-collapse: collapse">
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="width: 75%; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD STYLE="width: 25%; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; border-bottom: Black 1pt solid">/s/Mark St. Pierre</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD STYLE="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt">Mark St. Pierre</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD STYLE="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt">President and Chief Executive Officer</TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<DESCRIPTION>EX-32.2
<TEXT>
<HTML>
<HEAD>
     <TITLE></TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif">

<P STYLE="margin: 0"></P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center"><FONT STYLE="text-transform: uppercase">Exhibit
</FONT>32.2</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center">Certification of the Principal Financial Officer
pursuant to 18 U.S.C. Section 1350,</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center">as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley
Act of 2002</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify">In connection with this annual report of Espey
Mfg. &amp; Electronics Corp. (the &quot;Company&quot;) on Form 10-K for the period ended June 30, 2012 as filed with the Securities
and Exchange Commission on the date hereof (the &ldquo;report&rdquo;), I, David O&rsquo;Neil, Principal Financial Officer of the
Company, certify, pursuant to 18 U.S.C. Section 1350, as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that
to my knowledge:</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">&nbsp;</P>

<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.5in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.5in">1.</TD><TD>The report fully complies with the requirements of Section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934; and</TD></TR></TABLE>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.5in">&nbsp;</P>

<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
<TD STYLE="width: 0.5in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.5in">2.</TD><TD>The information contained in this report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of
operations of the Company.</TD></TR></TABLE>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">Date: September 13, 2012</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center">&nbsp;</P>

<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" STYLE="width: 100%; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; border-collapse: collapse">
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="width: 75%; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD STYLE="width: 25%; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; border-bottom: Black 1pt solid">/s/David O&rsquo;Neil</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD STYLE="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt">David O&rsquo;Neil</TD></TR>
<TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">
    <TD STYLE="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD STYLE="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt">Treasurer and Principal Financial Officer</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: center">&nbsp;</P>

    <us-gaap:NatureOfOperations contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;Note 1. Nature&#13;of operations&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Espey Mfg. &amp;#38; Electronics Corp. (the Company)&#13;is a manufacturer of electronic equipment used primarily in military and industrial applications. The principal markets for the&#13;Company's products are companies that provide electronic support to both military and industrial applications.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:NatureOfOperations>
    <us-gaap:SignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Note 2. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Inventory Valuation, Cost Estimation and Revenue&#13;Recognition&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Raw materials are valued at weighted average&#13;cost.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Inventoried work relating to contracts in process&#13;and work in process is valued at actual production cost, including factory overhead incurred to date. Work in process represents&#13;spare units; parts and other inventory items acquired or produced to service units previously sold or to meet anticipated future&#13;orders. The cost elements of contracts in process and work in process consist of production costs of goods and services currently&#13;in process and overhead. Provision for losses on contracts is made when the existence of such losses becomes probable and estimable.&#13;The costs attributed to units delivered under contracts are based on the estimated average cost of all units expected to be produced.&#13;Certain contracts are expected to extend beyond twelve months.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="color: black"&gt;Revenue is recognized&#13;on contracts in the period in which the units are delivered and billed (units-of-delivery method). &lt;/font&gt;A significant portion&#13;of our business is comprised of development and production contracts. Generally, revenues on long-term fixed-price contracts are&#13;recorded on a percentage of completion basis using units of delivery as the measurement basis for progress toward completion.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Percentage of completion accounting requires&#13;judgment relative to expected sales, estimating costs and making assumptions related to technical issues and delivery schedules.&#13;Contract costs include material, subcontract costs, labor and an allocation of overhead costs. The estimation of cost at completion&#13;of a contract is subject to numerous variables involving contract costs and estimates as to the length of time to complete the&#13;contract. Given the significance of the estimation processes and judgments described above, it is possible that materially different&#13;amounts of expected sales and contract costs could be recorded if different assumptions were used, based on changes in circumstances,&#13;in the estimation process. When a change in expected sales value or estimated cost is determined, changes are reflected in current&#13;period earnings.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Depreciation&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Depreciation of plant and equipment is computed&#13;on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the assets.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;Estimated&#13;useful lives of depreciable assets are as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: #CCEEFF"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 80%; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Buildings and improvements&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 20%; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right"&gt;10 &amp;#150; 40 years&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Machinery and equipment&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right"&gt;3 - 20 years&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: #CCEEFF"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Furniture and fixtures&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right"&gt;7 &amp;#150; 10 years&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Income Taxes&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company follows the provisions of ASC Topic&#13;740-10, &amp;#34;Accounting for Income Taxes.&amp;#34;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Under the provisions of ASC 740-10, deferred&#13;tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement&#13;carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax bases. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured&#13;using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be&#13;recovered or settled. The effect on deferred taxes and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in earnings in the period&#13;that includes the enactment date. In addition, ASC 740-10 requires that the tax benefit of tax-deductible dividends on unallocated&#13;ESOP shares be recorded as a direct addition to retained earnings rather than as a reduction of income tax expense.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 12pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Cash and Cash Equivalents&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Cash and cash equivalents consist of cash in&#13;banks, certificates of deposit, and money market funds. The Company considers all highly liquid investments with original maturities&#13;of three months or less to be cash equivalents.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Investment Securities&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company accounts for its investments in&#13;accordance with ASC 320-10-25, &amp;#147;Accounting for Certain Investments in Debt and Equity Securities.&amp;#148; Investment securities&#13;at June 30, 2012 and June 30, 2011 consist of certificates of deposit and municipal bonds. The Company classifies investment securities&#13;as available-for-sale. Unrealized holding gains and losses, net of related tax effect, on available-for-sale securities are excluded&#13;from earnings and are reported as a separate component of stockholders&amp;#146; equity until realized. Realized gains and losses&#13;for securities classified as available-for-sale are included in earnings and are determined using the specific identification method.&#13;Interest income is recognized when earned. &lt;font style="color: black"&gt;Fair values are based on quoted market prices available as&#13;of the balance sheet date.&amp;#160; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Accounts receivable and allowance for doubtful&#13;accounts&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company extends credit to its customers&#13;in the normal course of business and collateral is generally not required for trade receivables. Exposure to credit risk is controlled&#13;through the use of credit approvals, credit limits and monitoring procedures. Accounts receivable are reported net of an allowance&#13;for doubtful accounts. The Company estimates the allowance based on its analysis of specific balances. An account is generally&#13;considered past due after thirty (30)&amp;#160;days from the invoice date. Based on these factors, there was an allowance for doubtful&#13;accounts of $3,000 at June 30, 2012. Changes to the allowance for doubtful accounts are charged to expense and reduced by charge-offs,&#13;net of recoveries.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Per Share Amounts&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;ASC 260-10 &amp;#147;Earnings Per Share&amp;#148;&#13;requires the Company to calculate net income (loss) per share based on basic and diluted net income (loss) per share, as defined.&#13;Basic EPS excludes dilution and is computed by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted average number of shares outstanding&#13;for the period. Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities or other contracts to issue common stock&#13;were exercised or converted into common stock. The dilutive effect of outstanding options issued by the Company are reflected in&#13;diluted EPS using the treasury stock method. Under the treasury stock method, options will only have a dilutive effect when the&#13;average market price of common stock during the period exceeds the exercise price of the options.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Comprehensive Income&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Comprehensive income consists of net income&#13;and other comprehensive income. Other comprehensive income for fiscal year ended June 30, 2012 consists of unrealized holding gains&#13;and losses on available-for-sale securities. Comprehensive income for the years ended June 30, 2011 is equal to net income.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Use of Estimates&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The preparation of financial statements in&#13;conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates&#13;and assumptions that affect the reported amount of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at&#13;the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results&#13;could differ from those estimates.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Investment Tax Credits&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Investment tax credits are accounted for as&#13;a reduction of income tax expense in the year taxes payable are reduced.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Reclassifications&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Certain reclassifications may have been made&#13;to the prior year financial statements to conform to the current year presentation.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 12pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin: 0"&gt;Recently Issued Accounting Standards&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;In May 2011, the FASB issued Accounting Standards&#13;Update No. 2011-04, topic 820, &amp;#147;Fair Value Measurement,&amp;#148; to improve the comparability of fair value measurements presented&#13;and disclosed in financial statements prepared in accordance with United States GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards.&#13;Some of the amendments clarify the Board&amp;#146;s intent about the application of existing fair value measurement requirements.&#13;Other amendments change a particular principle or requirement for measuring fair value or for disclosing information about fair&#13;value measurements. Specifically, the guidance requires additional disclosures for fair value measurements that are based on significant&#13;unobservable inputs. The updated guidance is to be applied prospectively and is effective for the Company&amp;#146;s interim and annual&#13;periods beginning January 1, 2012. The adoption of this guidance is not expected to have a material impact on the Company&amp;#146;s&#13;consolidated financial statements.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;FASB Accounting Standards Update 2011-05, &amp;#34;Presentation&#13;of Comprehensive Income,&amp;#34; was issued in June 2011 to be effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011. Comprehensive&#13;income includes certain items that are recognized as &amp;#34;other comprehensive income&amp;#34; (&amp;#34;OCI&amp;#34;) and are excluded&#13;from net income. Examples include unrealized gains/losses on certain investments and gains/losses on derivative instruments designated&#13;as hedges. Under provisions of the update, the components of OCI must be presented in one of two formats: either (i) together with&#13;net income in a continuous statement of comprehensive income or (ii) in a second statement of comprehensive income to immediately&#13;follow the income statement. An existing option to present the components of OCI as part of the statement of changes in shareholders'&#13;equity is being eliminated. The Company expects the update to have minimal effect on its financial statements. The FASB recently&#13;issued Accounting Standards Update (ASU 2011-12) that defers the effective date of the requirement to present separate line items&#13;on the income statement for reclassification adjustments of items out of accumulated other comprehensive income into net income.&#13;The deferral is temporary until the Board reconsiders the operational concerns and needs of financial statement users. The Board&#13;has not yet established a timetable for its reconsideration.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Impairment of Long-Lived Assets&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Long-lived assets, including property, plant,&#13;and equipment, are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an&#13;asset may not be recoverable. Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of&#13;an asset to estimated undiscounted future cash flows expected to be generated by the asset. If the carrying amount of an asset&#13;exceeds its estimated future cash flows, an impairment charge is recognized by the amount by which the carrying amount of the asset&#13;exceeds the fair value of the asset. Assets to be disposed of are separately presented in the balance sheet and reported at the&#13;lower of the carrying amount or fair value less costs to sell, and no longer depreciated. The assets and liabilities of a disposed&#13;group classified as held for sale are presented separately in the appropriate asset and liability sections of the balance sheet.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Concentrations of Risk&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The market for our defense electronics products&#13;is largely dependent on the availability of new contracts from the United States and foreign governments to prime contractors to&#13;which we provide components. Any decline in expenditures by the United States or foreign governments may have an adverse effect&#13;on our financial performance.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Generally, U.S. Government contracts are subject&#13;to procurement laws and regulations. Some of the Company&amp;#146;s contracts are governed by the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR),&#13;which lays out uniform policies and procedures for acquiring goods and services by the U.S. Government, and agency-specific acquisition&#13;regulations that implement or supplement the FAR. For example, the Department of Defense implements the FAR through the Defense&#13;Federal Acquisition Regulation (DFAR).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The FAR also contains guidelines and regulations&#13;for managing a contract after award, including conditions under which contracts may be terminated, in whole or in part, at the&#13;government&amp;#146;s convenience or for default. If a contract is terminated for the convenience of the government, a contractor&#13;is entitled to receive payments for its allowable costs and, in general, the proportionate share of fees or earnings for the work&#13;done. If a contract is terminated for default, the government generally pays for only the work it has accepted. These regulations&#13;also subject the Company to financial audits and other reviews by the government of its costs, performance, accounting and general&#13;business practices relating to its contracts, which may result in adjustment of the Company&amp;#146;s contract-related costs and&#13;fees.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:SignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock>
    <esp:InventoryValuationCostEstimationAndRevenueRecognitionPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Inventory Valuation, Cost Estimation and Revenue&#13;Recognition&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Raw materials are valued at weighted average&#13;cost.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Inventoried work relating to contracts in process&#13;and work in process is valued at actual production cost, including factory overhead incurred to date. Work in process represents&#13;spare units; parts and other inventory items acquired or produced to service units previously sold or to meet anticipated future&#13;orders. The cost elements of contracts in process and work in process consist of production costs of goods and services currently&#13;in process and overhead. Provision for losses on contracts is made when the existence of such losses becomes probable and estimable.&#13;The costs attributed to units delivered under contracts are based on the estimated average cost of all units expected to be produced.&#13;Certain contracts are expected to extend beyond twelve months.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;font style="color: black"&gt;Revenue is recognized&#13;on contracts in the period in which the units are delivered and billed (units-of-delivery method). &lt;/font&gt;A significant portion&#13;of our business is comprised of development and production contracts. Generally, revenues on long-term fixed-price contracts are&#13;recorded on a percentage of completion basis using units of delivery as the measurement basis for progress toward completion.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Percentage of completion accounting requires&#13;judgment relative to expected sales, estimating costs and making assumptions related to technical issues and delivery schedules.&#13;Contract costs include material, subcontract costs, labor and an allocation of overhead costs. The estimation of cost at completion&#13;of a contract is subject to numerous variables involving contract costs and estimates as to the length of time to complete the&#13;contract. Given the significance of the estimation processes and judgments described above, it is possible that materially different&#13;amounts of expected sales and contract costs could be recorded if different assumptions were used, based on changes in circumstances,&#13;in the estimation process. When a change in expected sales value or estimated cost is determined, changes are reflected in current&#13;period earnings.&lt;/p&gt;</esp:InventoryValuationCostEstimationAndRevenueRecognitionPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:DepreciationDepletionAndAmortizationPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Depreciation&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Depreciation of plant and equipment is computed&#13;on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the assets.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;Estimated&#13;useful lives of depreciable assets are as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: #CCEEFF"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 80%; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Buildings and improvements&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 20%; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right"&gt;10 &amp;#150; 40 years&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Machinery and equipment&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right"&gt;3 - 20 years&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: #CCEEFF"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Furniture and fixtures&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right"&gt;7 &amp;#150; 10 years&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;</us-gaap:DepreciationDepletionAndAmortizationPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:IncomeTaxPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Income Taxes&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company follows the provisions of ASC Topic&#13;740-10, &amp;#34;Accounting for Income Taxes.&amp;#34;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Under the provisions of ASC 740-10, deferred&#13;tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement&#13;carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax bases. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured&#13;using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be&#13;recovered or settled. The effect on deferred taxes and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in earnings in the period&#13;that includes the enactment date. In addition, ASC 740-10 requires that the tax benefit of tax-deductible dividends on unallocated&#13;ESOP shares be recorded as a direct addition to retained earnings rather than as a reduction of income tax expense.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:IncomeTaxPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:CashAndCashEquivalentsPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Cash and Cash Equivalents&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Cash and cash equivalents consist of cash in&#13;banks, certificates of deposit, and money market funds. The Company considers all highly liquid investments with original maturities&#13;of three months or less to be cash equivalents.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:CashAndCashEquivalentsPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:InvestmentPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Investment Securities&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company accounts for its investments in&#13;accordance with ASC 320-10-25, &amp;#147;Accounting for Certain Investments in Debt and Equity Securities.&amp;#148; Investment securities&#13;at June 30, 2012 and June 30, 2011 consist of certificates of deposit and municipal bonds. The Company classifies investment securities&#13;as available-for-sale. Unrealized holding gains and losses, net of related tax effect, on available-for-sale securities are excluded&#13;from earnings and are reported as a separate component of stockholders&amp;#146; equity until realized. Realized gains and losses&#13;for securities classified as available-for-sale are included in earnings and are determined using the specific identification method.&#13;Interest income is recognized when earned. &lt;font style="color: black"&gt;Fair values are based on quoted market prices available as&#13;of the balance sheet date.&amp;#160; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:InvestmentPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:TradeAndOtherAccountsReceivablePolicy contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Accounts receivable and allowance for doubtful&#13;accounts&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company extends credit to its customers&#13;in the normal course of business and collateral is generally not required for trade receivables. Exposure to credit risk is controlled&#13;through the use of credit approvals, credit limits and monitoring procedures. Accounts receivable are reported net of an allowance&#13;for doubtful accounts. The Company estimates the allowance based on its analysis of specific balances. An account is generally&#13;considered past due after thirty (30)&amp;#160;days from the invoice date. Based on these factors, there was an allowance for doubtful&#13;accounts of $3,000 at June 30, 2012. Changes to the allowance for doubtful accounts are charged to expense and reduced by charge-offs,&#13;net of recoveries.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:TradeAndOtherAccountsReceivablePolicy>
    <us-gaap:EarningsPerSharePolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Per Share Amounts&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;ASC 260-10 &amp;#147;Earnings Per Share&amp;#148;&#13;requires the Company to calculate net income (loss) per share based on basic and diluted net income (loss) per share, as defined.&#13;Basic EPS excludes dilution and is computed by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted average number of shares outstanding&#13;for the period. Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities or other contracts to issue common stock&#13;were exercised or converted into common stock. The dilutive effect of outstanding options issued by the Company are reflected in&#13;diluted EPS using the treasury stock method. Under the treasury stock method, options will only have a dilutive effect when the&#13;average market price of common stock during the period exceeds the exercise price of the options.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:EarningsPerSharePolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:ComprehensiveIncomePolicyPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Comprehensive Income&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Comprehensive income consists of net income&#13;and other comprehensive income. Other comprehensive income for fiscal year ended June 30, 2012 consists of unrealized holding gains&#13;and losses on available-for-sale securities. Comprehensive income for the years ended June 30, 2011 is equal to net income.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:ComprehensiveIncomePolicyPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:UseOfEstimates contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Use of Estimates&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The preparation of financial statements in&#13;conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates&#13;and assumptions that affect the reported amount of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at&#13;the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results&#13;could differ from those estimates.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:UseOfEstimates>
    <esp:InvestmentTaxCreditsPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Investment Tax Credits&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Investment tax credits are accounted for as&#13;a reduction of income tax expense in the year taxes payable are reduced.&lt;/p&gt;</esp:InvestmentTaxCreditsPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:NewAccountingPronouncementsPolicyPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0"&gt;Recently Issued Accounting Standards&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;In May 2011, the FASB issued Accounting Standards&#13;Update No. 2011-04, topic 820, &amp;#147;Fair Value Measurement,&amp;#148; to improve the comparability of fair value measurements presented&#13;and disclosed in financial statements prepared in accordance with United States GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards.&#13;Some of the amendments clarify the Board&amp;#146;s intent about the application of existing fair value measurement requirements.&#13;Other amendments change a particular principle or requirement for measuring fair value or for disclosing information about fair&#13;value measurements. Specifically, the guidance requires additional disclosures for fair value measurements that are based on significant&#13;unobservable inputs. The updated guidance is to be applied prospectively and is effective for the Company&amp;#146;s interim and annual&#13;periods beginning January 1, 2012. The adoption of this guidance is not expected to have a material impact on the Company&amp;#146;s&#13;consolidated financial statements.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;FASB Accounting Standards Update 2011-05, &amp;#34;Presentation&#13;of Comprehensive Income,&amp;#34; was issued in June 2011 to be effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011. Comprehensive&#13;income includes certain items that are recognized as &amp;#34;other comprehensive income&amp;#34; (&amp;#34;OCI&amp;#34;) and are excluded&#13;from net income. Examples include unrealized gains/losses on certain investments and gains/losses on derivative instruments designated&#13;as hedges. Under provisions of the update, the components of OCI must be presented in one of two formats: either (i) together with&#13;net income in a continuous statement of comprehensive income or (ii) in a second statement of comprehensive income to immediately&#13;follow the income statement. An existing option to present the components of OCI as part of the statement of changes in shareholders'&#13;equity is being eliminated. The Company expects the update to have minimal effect on its financial statements. The FASB recently&#13;issued Accounting Standards Update (ASU 2011-12) that defers the effective date of the requirement to present separate line items&#13;on the income statement for reclassification adjustments of items out of accumulated other comprehensive income into net income.&#13;The deferral is temporary until the Board reconsiders the operational concerns and needs of financial statement users. The Board&#13;has not yet established a timetable for its reconsideration.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:NewAccountingPronouncementsPolicyPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:ImpairmentOrDisposalOfLongLivedAssetsPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Impairment of Long-Lived Assets&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Long-lived assets, including property, plant,&#13;and equipment, are reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an&#13;asset may not be recoverable. Recoverability of assets to be held and used is measured by a comparison of the carrying amount of&#13;an asset to estimated undiscounted future cash flows expected to be generated by the asset. If the carrying amount of an asset&#13;exceeds its estimated future cash flows, an impairment charge is recognized by the amount by which the carrying amount of the asset&#13;exceeds the fair value of the asset. Assets to be disposed of are separately presented in the balance sheet and reported at the&#13;lower of the carrying amount or fair value less costs to sell, and no longer depreciated. The assets and liabilities of a disposed&#13;group classified as held for sale are presented separately in the appropriate asset and liability sections of the balance sheet.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:ImpairmentOrDisposalOfLongLivedAssetsPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:ConcentrationRiskCreditRisk contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Concentrations of Risk&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The market for our defense electronics products&#13;is largely dependent on the availability of new contracts from the United States and foreign governments to prime contractors to&#13;which we provide components. Any decline in expenditures by the United States or foreign governments may have an adverse effect&#13;on our financial performance.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Generally, U.S. Government contracts are subject&#13;to procurement laws and regulations. Some of the Company&amp;#146;s contracts are governed by the Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR),&#13;which lays out uniform policies and procedures for acquiring goods and services by the U.S. Government, and agency-specific acquisition&#13;regulations that implement or supplement the FAR. For example, the Department of Defense implements the FAR through the Defense&#13;Federal Acquisition Regulation (DFAR).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The FAR also contains guidelines and regulations&#13;for managing a contract after award, including conditions under which contracts may be terminated, in whole or in part, at the&#13;government&amp;#146;s convenience or for default. If a contract is terminated for the convenience of the government, a contractor&#13;is entitled to receive payments for its allowable costs and, in general, the proportionate share of fees or earnings for the work&#13;done. If a contract is terminated for default, the government generally pays for only the work it has accepted. These regulations&#13;also subject the Company to financial audits and other reviews by the government of its costs, performance, accounting and general&#13;business practices relating to its contracts, which may result in adjustment of the Company&amp;#146;s contract-related costs and&#13;fees.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:ConcentrationRiskCreditRisk>
    <esp:ScheduleOfEstimatedUsefulLivesOfDepreciableAssetsTableTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;Estimated&#13;useful lives of depreciable assets are as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: #CCEEFF"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 80%; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Buildings and improvements&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 20%; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right"&gt;10 &amp;#150; 40 years&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Machinery and equipment&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right"&gt;3 - 20 years&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: #CCEEFF"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Furniture and fixtures&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-left: 5.4pt; text-align: right"&gt;7 &amp;#150; 10 years&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;</esp:ScheduleOfEstimatedUsefulLivesOfDepreciableAssetsTableTextBlock>

   &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="2" style="text-align: center"&gt;Less than&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-bottom: black 1pt solid"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;</us-gaap:InvestmentsClassifiedByContractualMaturityDateTableTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:AvailableForSaleSecuritiesTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Note 3. Investment in Fair Value&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;ASC 820 establishes a fair value hierarchy&#13;which requires an entity to maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable inputs when measuring fair&#13;value. The standard describes three levels of inputs that may be used to measure fair value:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 24px"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 24px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#9642;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; text-align: justify"&gt;Level 1: Quoted prices (unadjusted) for identical assets or liabilities in active markets that the entity has the ability to access as of the measurement date.&amp;#148;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 12pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 24px"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 24px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#9642;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; text-align: justify"&gt;Level 2: Significant other observable inputs other than Level 1 prices such as quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities; quoted prices in markets that are not active; or other inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data.&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 12pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 24px"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 24px; font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&amp;#9642;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; text-align: justify"&gt;Level 3: Significant unobservable inputs that reflect a reporting entity&amp;#146;s own assumptions about the assumptions that market participants would use in pricing an asset or liability.&amp;#148;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Investment securities at June 30, 2012 consist&#13;of certificates of deposit and municipal bonds which are classified as available-for-sale securities and have been determined to&#13;be level 1 assets. The cost, gross unrealized gains, gross unrealized losses and fair value of available-for-sale securities by&#13;major security type at June 30, 2012 are as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="2" style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="2" style="text-align: right"&gt;Gross&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="2" style="text-align: right"&gt;Gross&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="2" style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The portfolio is diversified and highly liquid&#13;and primarily consists of investment grade fixed income instruments. At June 30, 2012, the Company did not have any investments&#13;in individual securities that have been in a continuous loss position to be temporary for more than 12 months. Due to the fact&#13;that the decline in market value is attributable to changes in interest rates and not credit quality, and because the severity&#13;and duration of the unrealized losses were not significant, the Company considered these unrealized losses to be temporary at June&#13;30, 2012.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; Under the units-of-delivery method, the related sale and cost of sales will not be reflected in the statement&#13;of income until the units under contract are shipped.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:LongTermContractsOrProgramsDisclosureTextBlock>

    <us-gaap:IncomeTaxDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;Note 7.    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 2.25pt double"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right"&gt;1,691,188&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 2.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 2.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 2.25pt double"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right"&gt;1,524,005&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 2.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Deferred income taxes reflect the impact of&#13;&amp;#34;temporary differences&amp;#34; between the amount of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and such amounts&#13;measured by tax laws and regulations. These &amp;#34;temporary differences&amp;#34; are determined in accordance with ASC 740-10.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The combined U.S. federal and state effective&#13;income tax rates of 27.8% and 28.3%, for 2012 and 2011 respectively, differed from the statutory U.S. federal income tax rate for&#13;the following reasons:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" colspan="2" style="border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;2012&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" colspan="2" style="border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;2011&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: #CCEEFF"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="width: 74%; padding-left: 5.4pt"&gt;U.S. federal statutory income tax rate&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="width: 2%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="width: 1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="width: 9%; text-align: right"&gt;34.0&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="width: 1%"&gt;%&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="width: 2%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="width: 1%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="width: 9%; text-align: right"&gt;34.0&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="width: 1%"&gt;%&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-left: 5.4pt"&gt;Increase (reduction) in rate resulting from:&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 1pt solid"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;387,709&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 2.5pt; padding-left: 5.4pt"&gt;Net deferred tax asset&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 2.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 2.25pt double"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right"&gt;200,494&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 2.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 2.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 2.25pt double"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right"&gt;89,826&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 2.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;In assessing the realizability of deferred&#13;tax assets, management considers whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will be&#13;realized. The ultimate realization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income during the&#13;periods in which those temporary differences become deductible. Management considers the scheduled reversal of deferred tax liabilities,&#13;projected future taxable income, and tax planning strategies in making this assessment. Based upon the level of historical taxable&#13;income and projection for future taxable income over the period in which the deferred tax assets are deductible, management believes&#13;it is more likely than not that the Company will realize the benefits of these temporary differences without consideration of a&#13;valuation allowance.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;As the result of the implementation of the&#13;FASB interpretation ASC 740-10, Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes &amp;#150; An Interpretation of ASC 740, the Company recognized&#13;no material adjustments to unrecognized tax benefits. As of June 30, 2012 and 2011, the Company has no unrecognized tax benefits.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company recognizes interest and penalties&#13;related to uncertain tax positions, if any, in general and administrative expense. As of June 30, 2012, the Company has not recorded&#13;any provision for accrued interest and penalties related to uncertain tax positions.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;By statute, tax years ending June 30, 2012&#13;and 2011 remain open to examination by the major taxing jurisdictions to which the Company is subject.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:IncomeTaxDisclosureTextBlock>

    <us-gaap:PensionAndOtherPostretirementBenefitsDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;Note 6. Pension&#13;Expense&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;Under terms of a negotiated union contract&#13;which expires on June 30, 2015, the Company is obligated to make contributions to a union-sponsored International Brotherhood of&#13;Electrical Workers Local 1799 defined benefit pension plan (Plan identifying number is 14-6065199) covering eligible employees.&#13;Such contributions and expenses are based upon hours worked at a specified rate and amounted to $103,486 in fiscal 2012 and $102,281&#13;in fiscal 2011. These contributions represent more than five percent of the total contributions. For the years beginning January&#13;1, 2012 and 2011, the Plan is in the &amp;#147;green zone&amp;#148; which means it is in neither endangered nor critical status. The&#13;Plan has used extended amortization provisions.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0"&gt;The Company sponsors a 401(k) plan for non-union workers with employee&#13;and employer matching contributions. The employer match is 10% of the employee contribution and was $39,005 and $33,664, for fiscal&#13;years 2012 and 2011, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:PensionAndOtherPostretirementBenefitsDisclosureTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:PensionAndOtherPostretirementBenefitExpense contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30" unitRef="USD" decimals="0">103486</us-gaap:PensionAndOtherPostretirementBenefitExpense>
    <us-gaap:PensionAndOtherPostretirementBenefitExpense contextRef="From2010-07-01to2011-06-30" unitRef="USD" decimals="0">102281</us-gaap:PensionAndOtherPostretirementBenefitExpense>
    <us-gaap:DefinedContributionPlanEmployerMatchingContributionPercent contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30" unitRef="Pure" decimals="INF">.10</us-gaap:DefinedContributionPlanEmployerMatchingContributionPercent>
    <esp:DefinedContributionPlanEmployersMatchingContribution contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30" unitRef="USD" decimals="0">39005</esp:DefinedContributionPlanEmployersMatchingContribution>
    <esp:DefinedContributionPlanEmployersMatchingContribution contextRef="From2010-07-01to2011-06-30" unitRef="USD" decimals="0">33664</esp:DefinedContributionPlanEmployersMatchingContribution>
    <esp:StockRightsPlanTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;Note 9. Stock&#13;Rights Plan&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company has a Shareholder Rights Plan that&#13;expires on December 31, 2019. Under this plan, common stock purchase rights were distributed as a dividend at the rate of one right&#13;for each share of common stock outstanding as of or issued subsequent to April 14, 1989. Each right entitles the holder thereof&#13;to buy one-half share of common stock of the Company at an exercise price of $25 per share subject to adjustment. The rights are&#13;exercisable only if a person or group acquires beneficial ownership of 15% or more of the Company's common stock or commences a&#13;tender or exchange offer which, if consummated, would result in the offer or individually or, together with all affiliates and&#13;associates thereof, being the beneficial owner of 15% or more of the Company's common stock.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;If a 15% or larger shareholder should engage&#13;in certain self-dealing transactions or a merger with the Company in which the Company is the surviving corporation and its shares&#13;of common stock are not changed or converted into equity securities of any other person, or if any person were to become the beneficial&#13;owner of 15% or more of the Company's common stock, then each right not owned by such shareholder or related parties of such shareholder&#13;(all of which will be void) will entitle its holder to purchase, at the right's then current exercise price, shares of the Company's&#13;common stock having a value of twice the right's exercise price. In addition, if the Company is involved in any other merger or&#13;consolidation with, or sells 50% or more of its assets or earning power to another person, each right will entitle its holder to&#13;purchase, at the right's then current exercise price, shares of common stock of such other person having a value of twice the right's&#13;exercise price.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company generally is entitled to redeem&#13;the rights at one cent per right at any time until the 15th day (or 25th day if extended by the Company's Board of Directors) following&#13;public announcement that a 15% position has been acquired or the commencement of a tender or exchange offer which, if consummated,&#13;would result in the offer or, together with all affiliates and associates thereof, being the beneficial owner of 15% or more of&#13;the Company's common stock.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</esp:StockRightsPlanTextBlock>
    <esp:EmployeeStockOwnershipPlanTextBlock contextRef="From2011-07-01to2012-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;Note 10. Employee&#13;Stock Ownership Plan&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0.75in; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.75in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company sponsors a leveraged employee stock&#13;ownership plan (the &amp;#34;ESOP&amp;#34;) that covers all nonunion employees who work 1,000 or more hours per year and are employed&#13;on June 30. The Company makes annual contributions to the ESOP equal to the ESOP's debt service less dividends on unallocated shares&#13;received by the ESOP. All dividends on unallocated shares received by the ESOP are used to pay debt service. Dividends on allocated&#13;ESOP shares are recorded as a reduction of retained earnings. As the debt is repaid, shares are released and allocated to active&#13;employees, based on the proportion of debt service paid in the year. The Company accounts for its ESOP in accordance with FASB&#13;ASC 718-40. Accordingly, the shares purchased by the ESOP are reported as Unearned ESOP Shares in the statement of financial position.&#13;As shares are released or committed-to-be-released, the Company reports compensation expense equal to the current average market&#13;price of the shares, and the shares become outstanding for earnings-per-share (EPS) computations. ESOP compensation expense was&#13;$507,398 for the year ended June 30, 2012 and $502,990 for the year ended June 30, 2011. The ESOP shares as of June 30, 2012 and&#13;2011 were as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 2.25pt double"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right"&gt;3,609,349&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 2.25pt double; text-align: right"&gt;3,887,100&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 2.5pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</esp:EmployeeStockOwnershipPlanTextBlock>

   &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 1pt solid"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;136,666&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 1pt solid"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="border-bottom: black 1pt solid; text-align: right"&gt;157,500&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td nowrap="nowrap" style="padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom;
